After which will be produced fur the First Time, a Nautical Drama by the Author of the Pilot, &c. called the

VNCHCAPE
BELL:
OK,

H i e Dumb Sailor Boy of t h e Rooks.

THE BELL ROCK, or " INCHCAPE ROCK" ai it is more commonly dcsi«nated by mariner., is a sunken rock off the north eait roan ol
.Scotland, and was formerly very dangerous to sailor,. The abbots of Aberbrothock, or Aherbrothwick, a religious foundation standing .car the
coast, caused a largo Rell to be erected on the float, near to the rock, so as to rinq by the agitation of the sea—and by this simple means to indicate
<o the bewildered seaman the perilous situation in which he was placed. There is a tradition current among the inhabitant, of 'he coast, that th«
liell was cut from the float, and stolen, and that the person who committed this nefarious act afterwards met his fate by Rhtpwieck on this very
rock during a dark and stormy night.

you next find him at a
Tavern :--• noises most hideous are heard, and the Ghost enters anil sent* himself at the Table ; Juan with the
greatest composure, asks him to eat and drink, but if refused ; he t h e . (tearless of dangerJ appoint, to meet him
where hia remains he. intoned, at which place an awful s e n . of expostulation ensue,, but the Ghost finding all
intreaty to repentance useless, seizes him and casts him on the ground, he endeavours to escape, but in vain

W

' " ' ' e I" < , s , , l t ' '• "ic celebrated Drama, taken from Bulwees admired Novel, railed

Eugene Aram
O R p S T . R O B E R T ' S CAVE.

It is scarcely neeesHnry to remark thai this Drama is extracted almost literally from the celebrated Novel ; a
work thai, for intensity of interest, masterly conceptiim of-character, power of language, beauty and effect will
rurely find its parallel. The adaptor has only deviated from the original when obliged by stage necessity, and has
never resorted to Ins own Innauuije when he could avail himself of lliatof the novelist. That the drama was
highly successful, formed of materials so ledolunt of thrilling effect, and breathless interest as those affoided by
Mr. Buhvcr's novel, can he no matter of wonder ; the dramatia power and exc< s.ive skill displayed by Mi.
Bulwer in the management of his story, would have proved the ndaptoi to be a dullard indeed if he had not successfully availed himself of the advantage, offered him.

Sadden and Mysterious Appearance of the Warlock.

R O M A N T I C G L E N AMMMD T H E R O C K S .
The Warlock start* from his C a r . , and protects the innocent Countess Adela and her Child, who are pursue,!
by Ruffians, and conceals them.

A View of the Sea, huge Cliff and Rocky Shore.
The Counte.s MKI her B*be are overtaken by their pursuers, who are about to tear the Child from her embrace
when the Warlock appears ->« the Cliff, and denounces the " Vengeance ,.f Heaven upon the Guilty.''

A (.BMrmaiB AND w®m wt wmiYMimm

The Ruffians are about to murder the Infant, which they have succeeded in separating from it, Mother, when it
is rescued by the daring courage of Andrew, who defeats them —and the Piece ends

With the restoration of Adela to happiness

ACT S E C O N D O P E N S W I T H A V I E W O F

An Equestrian Statue of the Murdered Commandant.
On which, at the approach of J U A N , there instantly appears IN L E T T E R S O F B L O O D , upon the Pedestal
" Bij the* tfell, thy fate i decrted.
" Heaven will avenge the bltody tired"
But not dismayed at this, he invites the Statue to n Han.]-w, to which it assents :—you next find him at a
Tavern;—noises most hideous are heaid, and the Ghost enters and.seats himself at the Table : J U A N , w i t . the
greatest composure, asks him lo eat and drink, but is refused; he then (fearless .if dnnger) appoints to meet him
where h i . remains lie interred, at which place an awful scene of expostulation ensues, but the Ghost finding all
intrealy to reiientnncc useless, seizes him and casts hit), on the ground ; he endeavours to escape, but m vain for
he is destroyed by

THEATRE,
H a s great pleasure in announcing to the Nobility and Gentry of Plymouth, Devonport, Stonehouse, and
their Vicinities, that In- haa entered into an arrangement, by which he IR enabled to RE-OPRN the Plymouth
Theat-r* { b r i b e remainder of the Season.
In compliance with the understood wishes of many of the influential Inhabitants, Mr. H A Y is induced
to tryJUe experiment of a

GENERAL REDUCTION OF PRICES
.TO ALL PARTS OF THE HOU8E.

L o w e r J l o x e * 8 s . - U p p e r Boxes, a s . - P i t , l s . 6 d . - Gallery, I s ,
S E C O N D PRICK AT H A L F - P A S T E I G H T O'CLOCK.
LOWER BOXES, 2..
U P P E R B O X E S , la. 6 d . — P I T , It. ^ - G A L L E R Y , 6*.
Notwithstanding the very considerable reduction of the receipts, which must necessarily occur in
consequence of this measure, M r . H A Y p i e c e s himself to spare no exertion or expense in rendering the
T H E A T R E in every sense worthy the Patronage of the Public.

in popularity, interest and attraction, and
is allowed to be the r.ost splendid Ballet
ever produced on a Provincial Stage.

the Hill*. 5.—Thunder and I isrhiniot -Yells and Cries of Huntsmen. Horns, and Hound.— A Skeleton Stig, Hounds, Hems,,

elph fall prostrate, and the Enchantment ends.

THEATRE-ROYAL,
PLYMOUTH.
Stage Manager, Mr. 8 A M E R T 0 N ; Musical Director, Mr. TULLY, of the T. R. English
Opera, and MadamVestris; Property Maker, Mr. KELLY, from the T. R. Drury Lane.

Mr. G . C. Davenport begrs moist respectfully to inform
the Nobility, Gentry, and Inhabitants of Plymouth, that in
addition to his present Coonpany, he lias entered into En*
gag-ements with several distinguished Performers from
the Theatres Royal, London, who will successively appear
in the Plymouth Theatre, and trusts that ihe Arrangements he has made will insure thePatrooiage of all.

On Friday Evening, January 5,1838,
Will he presented the admired Comedy of

J O H N BULL
OR,

The Ihif/Mshmari's

Fireside.

at half-past Seven.
Ticket, to l.e had and Places taken at Mr. Rowe's, Box Office, 44, Rpdford-Street; also, of Mr. May,

of Visitors.

M r . G . C . Davenport begs most respectfully It) inform
the Nobility, Gentry, and Inhabitants or Plymouth, that in
addition to his present Company, he has entered into Engagements with several distinguished Performers from
the Theatres Royal. London, who will successively appeal*
in the Plymouth Theatre, and trusts that Hie Arrangements he has made will insure the Pati'onage of all.

From the Theatre-Royal, Adelphi, who will have the honour of making his

It is pronounce.! by Mi. Pres* to be the
most Splendid S|ie<tM<:le ever witnessed in this Theatre, ii abounds in n e w a n d

beautiful Scenery, magnificent Dresses, picturesque Groupings, warlike Combats between hosts of British Soldiers and fiery AflTrhans,
Bombardments, Escalades, burning Cities, falling Towns, and nil the

Kotfl-stirrintr accompaniment of defeat and victory. So excited was the Audience on
the first night of it*, production, that xt the fall of the Curtain, three hearty and
prolonged cheers were given from all parts of the House.

M R . J . I t . N E W C O M B E begs most respectfully t o announce to t h e Nobility, G e n t r y , a n d t h e Public g e n e r a l l y ,
at h e has succeeded a t considerable expense in forming an E n g a g e m e n t with the C E L E B R A T E D D A N C E R
that

MADEMOISELLE FLORA FABBRI,
Oj the Theatre, /ioyal,

Drury

Lane, and Academic

Hot/ale,

Pari*,

For T h r e e Night* only, on M o n d a j , Tuesday A W e i l n e s d a j
U t h . 15th a n d 16th, instant, in t h e gorgeous Ballet of L E D I A B L E A Q U A T R E , t h e success of which
# H M great in t h e Metropolis, that it not only drew crowded houses during t h e whole nf h e r engagement, b u t h a s
been commanded for t h e n e x t season, and M A D E M O I S E L L E F L O R A F A B R I ' S Continental E n g a g e m e n t ,
leferred to a latter period. S h e will be supported b y the same Foreign a n d English Artistes who shared h e r splendid
triumph in London •.—

MONSIEUR BRETIN,
MADEMOISELLE LOUISE,

The Gentry and Inhabitants of Plymouth, Devonport, Stonehouse, and Neighbourhood are respectfully

1°.

SECOND NIGHT OF " UNCLE TOM'S CABIN."

The a u o e . . . of t h i . rieoe has been boyond the nxo.t sanguine expectations. The powerful and truthful acting, joined
wltli the strong <,nme.tio intoreet of the drama, has placed It the first and best upon the list of piece, that Apeak to tho
heart and feeling'.. The naturally-painted Scenery i . of the greatest artiatical merit | and . o vivid are the piot.ar « of
mountain, lake, and river which are placed before the auditors, that they seem to live and breathe upon the very . <ot»
they illustrate. The novel nature of its general coin.truetioa,~its strontr appeal, to the human breast, for pity and c tn»i seratfon for a suffering and ill-used race, rondur lt» proneral feature, of .uch a character a . to create pleasure and
satisfaction in tho minds of all who witness this extraordinary performance.

Mr. J . Tai fount

Kegs most respectfully to announce that he will Open the
above Theatre (which has been Newly Painted and Embellished.

On M o n d a y n e x t , D e c . 2 6 , 1 8 3 6 ,
W i t h an efficient Company, and throws himself with the
utmost confidence on the kindness of an indulgent public.
T o the lovers of the Drama he pledges himself that everj
exertion shall be used to secure* their patronage and support.
Pieces will be produced with appropriate Scenery, Dresses,
&e. <ftc. Constables will be in atteoidance to preserve th<>
strictest order ; and in conclusion the Manager takes leave
Fo hope that the undermentioned prices will meet general
approbation.—
